articles.headline: Mistakes, I’ve Made a Few, Bush Tells Reporters
articles.snippet: President Bush was by turns impassioned, defiant and lighthearted in his last scheduled news conference.
articles.abstract: President Bush was by turns impassioned, defiant and lighthearted in his last scheduled news conference.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Bush held what he called “the ultimate exit interview” on Monday, using the final news conference of his presidency to dispute the idea that the nation’s “moral standing has been damaged” by his actions and to warn President-elect Barack Obama that, despite the turbulence in the economy, his most urgent priority must be fighting “an enemy that would like to attack America and Americans again.”

articles.headline: Israelis United on Gaza War as Censure Rises Abroad
articles.snippet: Israel’s critics abroad call the Gaza war a disproportionate response. In Israel, very few people see it that way.
articles.abstract: Israel’s critics abroad call the Gaza war a disproportionate response. In Israel, very few people see it that way.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM  To Israel’s critics abroad, the picture could not be clearer: Israel’s war in Gaza is a wildly disproportionate response to the rockets of Hamas, causing untold human suffering and bombing an already isolated and impoverished population into the Stone Age, and it must be stopped.

articles.headline: Obama’s Plan to Close Prison at Guantánamo May Take Year
articles.snippet: Barack Obama was said to be set to issue an executive order on his first full day in office directing the closing, which experts said would require an extensive effort.
articles.abstract: Barack Obama was said to be set to issue an executive order on his first full day in office directing the closing, which experts said would require an extensive effort.
articles.lead_paragraph: President-elect Barack Obama plans to issue an executive order on his first full day in office directing the closing of the Guantánamo Bay detention camp in Cuba, people briefed by Obama transition officials said Monday.
articles.byline: By William Glaberson and Helene Cooper

articles.headline: Gulf Oil States Seeking a Lead in Clean Energy
articles.snippet: Well aware of the limits of oil, the United Arab Emirates, Qatar and Saudi Arabia are aggressively pouring billions of dollars into green technologies.
articles.abstract: Well aware of the limits of oil, the United Arab Emirates, Qatar and Saudi Arabia are aggressively pouring billions of dollars into green technologies.
articles.lead_paragraph: ABU DHABI, United Arab Emirates  With one of the highest per capita carbon footprints in the world, these oil-rich emirates would seem an unlikely place for a green revolution.

articles.headline: Madoff Still Free on Bail; Signs Seen of Plea Deal
articles.snippet: Signs emerged that the lawyer for Bernard L. Madoff was actively negotiating a plea agreement that could conclude the baffling fraud case without a trial.
articles.abstract: Signs emerged that the lawyer for Bernard L. Madoff was actively negotiating a plea agreement that could conclude the baffling fraud case without a trial.
articles.lead_paragraph: A federal magistrate refused to revoke bail on Monday for Bernard L. Madoff, the financier accused of operating a $50 billion Ponzi scheme, while signs emerged that his lawyer was actively negotiating a plea agreement that could conclude the baffling fraud case without a trial.

articles.headline: Town Mourns Typical Businessman Who Took Atypical Risks
articles.snippet: The suicide of the German billionaire Adolf Merckle shocked the nation as much as it angered his tiny town, where he was eulogized at a service that overflowed the church.
articles.abstract: The suicide of the German billionaire Adolf Merckle shocked the nation as much as it angered his tiny town, where he was eulogized at a service that overflowed the church.
articles.lead_paragraph: BLAUBEUREN, Germany — When the body of Adolf Merckle was discovered on the railroad tracks here last week, authorities ruled the German billionaire’s death to be a suicide.

articles.headline: A Cash Machine Runs Low
articles.snippet: It seemed as if Citigroup was regaining a bit of trust on Wall Street, but as the struggling giant moved toward a deal with Morgan Stanley, all the old demons returned.
articles.abstract: It seemed as if Citigroup was regaining a bit of trust on Wall Street, but as the struggling giant moved toward a deal with Morgan Stanley, all the old demons returned.
articles.lead_paragraph: For a few brief weeks, it seemed as if Vikram S. Pandit, the chief executive of Citigroup, was regaining a bit of trust on Wall Street. But on Monday, as the struggling financial giant moved toward a deal with Morgan Stanley for its Smith Barney brokerage unit, all the old demons returned.

articles.headline: No Shortage of Advice on Mideast for Clinton
articles.snippet: As Hillary Rodham Clinton prepares to take over as secretary of state, a coterie of emissaries is pushing for a more balanced approach to the region.
articles.abstract: As Hillary Rodham Clinton prepares to take over as secretary of state, a coterie of emissaries is pushing for a more balanced approach to the region.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  As Hillary Rodham Clinton prepares to take over as secretary of state, a coterie of emissaries who have made the Arab-Israeli conflict their specialty for decades is pushing for a more assertive and balanced American approach to a region once again torn by war.

articles.headline: In Madoff, a Court Trusts
articles.snippet: Someone without a bank account like Bernard L. Madoff’s surely would be locked up by now. Of course, this has always been the way of the white-collar world.
articles.abstract: Someone without a bank account like Bernard L. Madoff’s surely would be locked up by now. Of course, this has always been the way of the white-collar world.

articles.headline: Big Health Insurer Agrees to Update Its Fee Data
articles.snippet: New York’s attorney general ordered an overhaul of the way insurers decide what to pay for out-of-network care.
articles.abstract: New York’s attorney general ordered an overhaul of the way insurers decide what to pay for out-of-network care.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a settlement with one of the nation’s biggest insurers, New York’s attorney general, Andrew M. Cuomo, has ordered an overhaul of the databases the industry uses to determine how much of a medical bill is paid when a patient uses an out-of-network doctor.
articles.byline: By Danny Hakim and Reed Abelson
